Posted By: Tsuichoi (10/30/2010 4:04:29 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
+ it let's us play cards and ignore their color requirements  
+ it easily becomes out of hand once it starts going, be it with cards generating extra turns, drawing you more cards, returning cards from graveyard to hand or whatever  
+ you can play the mirror, and next time it triggers, in response to the trigger, you can activate it and imprint something. once the triggered effect of the mirror resolves, it will allow you to play the imprinted card, even though it was not yet imprinted when the trigger was put on the stack  
  
- doesnt work on spells with X in the cost  
- must trigger several times to be of use. if it triggers just once or not at all, you wasted cards and 5 mana  
- if it gets destroyed / bounced / stopped in any way, you lose two or more cards at once
posts.html:
+ it let's us play cards and ignore their color requirements
+ it easily becomes out of hand once it starts going, be it with cards generating extra turns, drawing you more cards, returning cards from graveyard to hand or whatever
+ you can play the mirror, and next time it triggers, in response to the trigger, you can activate it and imprint something. once the triggered effect of the mirror resolves, it will allow you to play the imprinted card, even though it was not yet imprinted when the trigger was put on the stack

- doesnt work on spells with X in the cost
- must trigger several times to be of use. if it triggers just once or not at all, you wasted cards and 5 mana
- if it gets destroyed / bounced / stopped in any way, you lose two or more cards at once

posts.post_content: @Tsuichoi The mirror makes a virtual copy from the exiled one (read rulings below card pic), the card happens and then the virtual one is exiled, since its a token it ceases to exist as a state based action after all spells on the stack resolve and priority has been given to your opponent.
posts.html:
@Tsuichoi The mirror makes a virtual copy from the exiled one (read rulings below card pic), the card happens and then the virtual one is exiled, since its a token it ceases to exist as a state based action after all spells on the stack resolve and priority has been given to your opponent.

Posted By: Winterbane (11/17/2010 6:24:14 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Not constructed viable due to the cost compared to the lack-of-ensured-win, but fantastic in casual. It's virtually impossible to get card disadvantage with it too, as you can imprint a card in response to the triggered ability - so even if they Naturalize it at that point, the ability will still resolve and cast a copy of the exiled card, meaning that they'd get a 1 for 1.  
  
Time Warp seems like a pretty awesome card to imprint on it. "Oh, if you can't counter the copied spell or destroy the mirror then every turn for the rest of the game will be mine. GG".
posts.html:
Not constructed viable due to the cost compared to the lack-of-ensured-win, but fantastic in casual. It's virtually impossible to get card disadvantage with it too, as you can imprint a card in response to the triggered ability - so even if they Naturalize it at that point, the ability will still resolve and cast a copy of the exiled card, meaning that they'd get a 1 for 1.

Time Warp seems like a pretty awesome card to imprint on it. "Oh, if you can't counter the copied spell or destroy the mirror then every turn for the rest of the game will be mine. GG".
